childhood_context.html:
Childhood: {{BIRTH_YEAR}}-{{CHILDHOOD_END_YEAR}}

The smell of orange shag carpet and cigarette smoke. The feel of a vinyl car seat burning the backs of your thighs in August. The taste of Tang, which astronauts supposedly drank, mixed with tap water in a Tupperware pitcher. Your childhood was tactile in ways that no longer exist—everything had a texture, a temperature, a specific weight in your hands.

You were born the year Saigon fell, the year your parents watched helicopters lift off embassy rooftops while Gerald Ford tried to convince everyone things were fine. Pet Rocks were the hot gift that Christmas. Adults paid $3.95 for a rock in a box with breathing holes. This is what passed for irony before irony was invented.

At two, Star Wars exploded into existence, and suddenly every kid you knew wanted to be Luke Skywalker or Princess Leia. You had the action figures—the original Kenner ones with the telescoping lightsabers that became collectors' items. You lost most of them in the sandbox or the dog ate them. At five, Empire Strikes Back revealed that Vader was Luke's father, and some older kid at school ruined it for you before you saw it. Your first spoiler.

Saturday mornings were sacred. You woke up before your parents, poured yourself a bowl of Cap'n Crunch or Froot Loops, and planted yourself in front of the TV for Schoolhouse Rock between cartoons. 'I'm Just a Bill' taught you more about government than school did. 'Conjunction Junction' made grammar almost fun. You can still sing 'Three Is a Magic Number' from memory.

At six, MTV launched with 'Video Killed the Radio Star,' and suddenly music was something you watched. By eleven, you knew every frame of Michael Jackson's 'Thriller' video—the transformation, the zombies, the Vincent Price voiceover. You practiced the dance moves in your bedroom mirror. Everyone did.

You ate TV dinners in their aluminum trays, the ones with the crispy apple dessert in the corner. Hamburger Helper when Mom was tired. Swanson's fried chicken on special occasions. Jiffy Pop on the stovetop, watching the foil dome rise until it looked ready to burst. You drank Hi-C and Kool-Aid with enough sugar to fuel a small city. Your parents smoked inside, the car windows rolled up, and somehow you all survived.

At eleven, Challenger exploded. Your whole class was watching—a teacher was going to space. You remember the teachers' faces more than the explosion itself.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Generation X

Generation X. The forgotten middle child. The latchkey generation. The slackers who turned out to be running things while everyone was busy arguing about Boomers and Millennials. There are only 65 million of you—dwarfed by 76 million Boomers above and 72 million Millennials below—which means you've never had the voting power to bend politics your way. You learned to work around systems rather than through them.

You were seven when your parents might have divorced—1982, when divorce rates peaked. Half your friends came from 'broken homes,' which was the term adults used, as if families were vases that got knocked off shelves. You came home to empty houses with a key around your neck, made yourself snacks, watched TV until someone got home. This wasn't neglect; it was how things were. Authority figures lie, institutions fail, trust is earned, not given. You raised yourself, and it shows.

The Cold War was background radiation for your entire childhood. You practiced duck-and-cover drills in elementary school. 'The Day After' aired when you were eight, showing nuclear annihilation in prime time, and your parents tried to explain that everything would probably be fine. At fourteen, the Berlin Wall fell. At sixteen, the Soviet Union collapsed. The enemy your entire childhood had been organized around just... disappeared. That particular whiplash never quite resolved.

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, you were {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. Your generation invented the ironic detachment that became the default setting for American culture. You learned to hedge everything with knowing smirks and air quotes because sincerity was dangerous. If you didn't get your hopes up, they couldn't be crushed. If you didn't believe in institutions, you couldn't be betrayed when they failed. 'Whatever' wasn't apathy—it was armor.

You watched Watergate as a toddler, Iran-Contra as a preteen, the savings and loan crisis as a teenager. By the time Enron collapsed and the 2008 crash happened, you were so unsurprised it barely registered. Of course the system was rigged. Of course the powerful protected themselves. Of course regular people got screwed. You can still entertain yourself without a screen. That's a superpower now.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

Jaws came out the summer you were born—a rubber shark that made an entire generation afraid of the ocean. Your parents saw it in theaters, probably on a date, definitely before they had you to worry about. 'Bohemian Rhapsody' dropped that same year, six minutes of operatic weirdness that somehow became the greatest rock song ever recorded. Bruce Springsteen released Born to Run, capturing the desperate hunger to escape small towns that would define your generation.

Saturday Night Live premiered on October 11, 1975, four months after you were born. Dan Aykroyd, John Belushi, Gilda Radner, Chevy Chase—not that you'd understand any of it until years later, when you caught reruns and realized your parents' sense of humor came from somewhere. 'Live from New York, it's Saturday Night!' became the sound of staying up past your bedtime.

At two, you experienced Star Wars. Even if you were too young to remember seeing it, you absorbed it through merchandise, reruns, and the fact that every kid you'd ever meet had opinions about Han Solo. The Kenner action figures were everywhere—Luke, Leia, Darth Vader, the Millennium Falcon that took up half your closet. You learned to play Star Wars before you learned to read.

Your childhood TV was The Muppet Show, Happy Days, Laverne & Shirley, Good Times, and The Jeffersons. Diff'rent Strokes asked 'Whatchoo talkin' bout, Willis?' so many times it became a cultural tic. The A-Team blew things up without ever actually hurting anyone. Knight Rider had a talking car, which seemed like the future. You stayed up late to watch M*A*S*H, not fully understanding why adults cared so much about a war that ended before you were born.

At ten, The Breakfast Club came out—five teenagers in Saturday detention, talking about their problems. John Hughes understood something no adult filmmaker had before: that teenagers were actual people with actual inner lives. By twelve, Ferris Bueller was teaching you that life moves pretty fast, and you believed it. Pretty in Pink made Molly Ringwald the face of your generation's romantic confusion.

At sixteen, Nirvana's Nevermind dropped and everything changed. 'Smells Like Teen Spirit' made flannel shirts and unwashed hair into a fashion statement. Grunge wasn't just music—it was permission to be angry and sad and confused all at once. Pearl Jam, Soundgarden, Alice in Chains—Seattle was suddenly the center of the universe. You probably owned Doc Martens. You definitely had opinions about Eddie Vedder.

At nineteen, Kurt Cobain died. April 8, 1994. You remember where you were when you heard. The voice of your generation's alienation, gone at twenty-seven. The MTV News coverage. The makeshift memorials. The sense that something irreplaceable had been lost. You were old enough to grieve, young enough that grief still felt new.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

The year you were born, Bill Gates and Paul Allen founded Microsoft in Albuquerque, writing BASIC for the Altair 8800—a computer that came as a kit and did almost nothing useful. The personal computer revolution was starting in garages and spare bedrooms, and you'd grow up alongside it, watching technology transform from hobbyist curiosity to the infrastructure of everything.

Your childhood was entirely analog. You changed TV channels by walking across the room—or by being the youngest kid, which made you the remote control. You dialed phones with rotary dials, the plastic clicking back to zero after each number. You looked things up in encyclopedias, those heavy books that were already outdated by the time they were printed. You used card catalogs at the library, flipping through index cards to find books.

At eight, you got an Atari 2600, or your friends did, and suddenly video games were something you played at home instead of at arcades. Space Invaders. Pac-Man. Pitfall. The graphics were blocks and bleeps, but they felt like the future. You probably wore out the joystick playing Asteroids.

At ten, the Macintosh launched with that famous Super Bowl commercial—the woman throwing a hammer at Big Brother. At eleven, the Nintendo Entertainment System arrived and resurrected the video game industry. Super Mario Bros. changed everything. The Legend of Zelda taught you to save your progress on a battery-powered cartridge that would eventually die, taking your saved games with it.

At twelve, your school got a computer lab. Apple IIe machines with green text on black screens. You learned to type on actual typewriters first, then on computers. Oregon Trail was educational, supposedly, though mainly you learned that everyone dies of dysentery. Where in the World Is Carmen Sandiego? taught you geography and how to use encyclopedias to cheat.

At eighteen, the World Wide Web went public. You were in college, or just starting out, when the internet became something regular people could use. At twenty-three, Google launched. At twenty-five, the dot-com boom was in full swing—stock options, foosball tables, companies with no business models valued at billions. At twenty-six, it all collapsed. You learned that 'new economy' was just 'old economy with better marketing.' The skepticism stuck.

You remember life before email, before cell phones, before the internet was everywhere. You know what boredom felt like when you couldn't just scroll something. You can read a physical map, remember phone numbers, entertain yourself without a screen. These are superpowers now, relics of a world that no longer exists. You bridge two eras—the last generation to grow up analog, the first to fully adapt to digital. You're fluent in both languages.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

April 30, 1975: Saigon fell. You were four months old. The last helicopter lifted off from the embassy roof while your parents watched on television, ending a war that had defined their entire adult lives. You don't remember it, but you grew up in its aftermath—the veterans who came home to nothing, the POW bracelets, the movies that would start coming when you were a teenager: Apocalypse Now, Platoon, Full Metal Jacket. Vietnam was the wound America couldn't stop picking at.

At five, someone shot Reagan outside the Hilton. You probably watched the footage replayed endlessly on the evening news. At six, AIDS appeared in the headlines, a mysterious disease killing gay men in San Francisco and New York. Nobody understood it yet. The fear and stigma would define the decade.

At four, the Iran hostage crisis began. For 444 days, Americans were held captive—a nightly reminder that American power had limits.

At eight, 241 American service members died in the Beirut barracks bombing. At nine, Michael Jackson's 'Thriller' video terrified and thrilled you in equal measure. At ten, 'We Are the World' tried to solve African famine through celebrity singalong. Your childhood was a strange mix of optimism and violence, morning in America and mourning for real.

At eleven, Challenger exploded. January 28, 1986. You saw it live at school—the moment that would define your generation's loss of innocence.

At fourteen, the Berlin Wall fell. November 9, 1989. People with sledgehammers, champagne, tears. David Hasselhoff on a crane, for reasons nobody ever fully explained. You watched it on TV and tried to understand what it meant. The enemy your entire childhood had been organized around just... wasn't the enemy anymore. At sixteen, the Soviet Union collapsed entirely. The Cold War ended with a whimper, not a bang.

At sixteen, the Gulf War happened—the first war broadcast live on CNN, green night-vision footage that looked like a video game. 'Smart bombs' and 'surgical strikes.' It was supposed to be quick and clean, Vietnam's mistakes corrected. You were young enough to believe some of that.

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, you were {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. You were at work when the first plane hit. By the time the second plane hit, everyone knew. You watched the towers fall on live television. You spent the rest of the day trying to reach people, confirm that friends in New York were alive, understand something that felt impossible. The world before that morning became a different country.

At thirty-three, the financial system nearly collapsed. You had a mortgage by then, maybe kids, definitely a 401(k) that lost half its value overnight. You watched friends lose houses. You watched banks get bailed out while regular people got nothing. 'Too big to fail' meant the consequences rolled downhill.

At forty-five, COVID. You worked from home, worried about aging parents, explained to your kids why they couldn't see friends. You'd lived through enough crises to know this would pass. That didn't make it easier. It just made you tired.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You graduated college around 1997, give or take, and walked straight into the greatest economic expansion since the 1960s. The dot-com boom was heating up. Companies were hiring anyone who could spell HTML. Stock options were being handed out like candy. Ping-pong tables in the office. Free snacks. The phrase 'internet millionaire' wasn't ironic yet. Some of you actually became one. Most of you didn't, but the optimism was intoxicating.

Then March 2000 happened. The NASDAQ peaked at 5,048, then began its long, humiliating slide. Suddenly all those startups with no revenue models were gone. The Aeron chairs were being sold at liquidation auctions. Pets.com and Webvan and all the rest became cautionary tales. The old social contract—work hard, stay loyal, retire with a pension—was being shredded in real time. You learned that 'disruptive' often meant 'unprofitable,' that stock options could expire worthless, that the new economy was just the old economy wearing a turtleneck.

If you'd been smart or lucky, you cashed out before the crash. If you hadn't, you went back to regular jobs and tried not to think about what might have been. Either way, you learned something valuable: bubbles pop. Hype dies. Job security became an oxymoron. The fundamentals always win eventually.

Your generation pioneered the work-life balance conversation, mostly because you watched your Boomer bosses sacrifice everything—weekends, vacations, families—for companies that would downsize them without hesitation. You saw loyalty repaid with pink slips. You watched middle managers worked to death get replaced by cheaper hires. You were the first generation to openly question whether the corporate ladder was worth climbing. The answer, for many of you: not if the rungs keep disappearing.

At {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}, the 2008 financial crisis arrived. At thirty-three, the 2008 crash hit. You were mid-career—established enough to have something to lose, young enough that you couldn't just retire early. You watched colleagues get laid off. You took on their work to prove you were essential. You learned that companies protect themselves first, always. 'We're all family here' meant nothing when the layoffs came.

Your management style, if you made it to management, tends toward benign neglect. You give people space because that's what you wanted when you were younger. You don't micromanage because you remember hating it. You're deeply skeptical of corporate jargon—'synergy' usually means layoffs, 'restructuring' means someone's getting fired. You've seen too many mission statements that meant nothing.

COVID normalized remote work when you were forty-five, but you'd been figuring out how to work independently since you were a latchkey kid heating up pizza rolls after school. You don't need constant supervision. You don't need an office to be productive. Working from home is just the adult version of coming home to an empty house and getting things done anyway.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Remember passing notes in class? The folded paper triangles, the intricate origami, the risk of getting caught? Remember when getting someone's phone number meant something, because calling their house meant potentially talking to their parents first? Remember mix tapes—actual cassette tapes—where the song selection was a declaration of feelings you couldn't say out loud?

You grew up in the divorce boom. Your parents, or your friends' parents, or seemingly everyone's parents, split up during the late '70s and '80s. No-fault divorce became standard. Custody arrangements became playground conversation. You learned early that 'forever' was often aspirational, that families reconfigured, that love wasn't enough if everything else fell apart.

This made you cautious. You dated longer before marrying. You cohabitated first to make sure. You'd seen what happened to people who rushed—your parents' friends, your friends' parents, half the adults you knew. Better to wait. Better to be sure. Better to protect yourself than to end up splitting assets and negotiating holidays.

You met partners the old-fashioned way: at parties, through friends, at work, in the dorms. By your late twenties, online dating existed—Match.com launched when you were twenty—but it was stigmatized. Admitting you met someone on the internet felt desperate, like you couldn't find someone in real life. 'We met through friends' was the cover story. The stigma faded eventually, but you remember when it was there.

Your communication style bridges eras. You wrote actual letters, on paper, with stamps. You learned email in your twenties, texting in your thirties. You can have a phone conversation without anxiety—unlike younger people who treat unexpected calls like ambushes. You remember when being unreachable was normal, when weekends meant you couldn't be found, when leaving the house meant being gone.

If you have kids, they're probably teenagers or young adults now. You watch them navigate social media, influencer culture, dating apps, whatever the current crisis is. You try to give them the independence you had—come home when the streetlights come on, figure it out, you'll be fine—but the world has fewer dark corners where kids can make mistakes unseen. Everything is documented now.

Your friendships have survived decades, divorces, distance. The people who matter have been around since high school or college. You don't need to see someone every week to consider them close. You can pick up exactly where you left off, years later, as if no time has passed. That's what happens when you've known someone for forty years.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Three major economic crashes hit during your prime earning years. The dot-com crash when you were twenty-five. The 2008 financial crisis when you were thirty-three. Add COVID's economic chaos at forty-five. Mortgage rates hit 18% in the early '80s. The market dropped 40% in 2008. Each one taught you the same lesson: the floor can drop out at any moment, and the people who caused it won't be the ones who pay.

But here's the thing: your timing was actually decent, compared to what came after. You could buy a house in the late '90s or early 2000s for something resembling a reasonable price. Student debt, if you had it, was measured in thousands, not hundreds of thousands. Entry-level jobs paid enough to live on.

The dot-com crash was your first real financial trauma. You watched paper millionaires become paper paupers. Stock options that were supposed to make you rich expired worthless. If you worked at a startup, you probably lost your job. The old social contract—work hard, stay loyal, retire with a pension—was being shredded in real time. You learned that bubbles pop, that 'new paradigm' is usually old hype, that the smart money exits before the dumb money notices.

You recovered. Built something. Then 2008 hit. You had a mortgage by then, maybe kids, definitely a 401(k) that lost half its value overnight. You watched friends get foreclosed. You watched banks get bailed out—$700 billion for the institutions that caused the crisis—while regular people got nothing. Job security became an oxymoron. 'Too big to fail' meant the consequences flowed downhill, as consequences always do.

Your financial psychology is cautious pessimism. You save because you've seen savings evaporate. You invest in index funds because you don't trust stock picks. You keep an emergency fund because emergencies happen—not might happen, will happen. You learned not to trust paper wealth, not to count on employer loyalty, not to assume the system will protect you.

You're in your peak earning years now, which is good because you're squeezed from both directions. Kids need college money—tuition tripled since you graduated. Parents need help—aging is expensive, and Medicare doesn't cover everything. The sandwich generation metaphor isn't a metaphor; you're literally paying in two directions while trying to save for a retirement that may or may not be possible.

Social Security will probably exist when you hit sixty-seven. Your 401(k) might be enough. The math works on paper. But paper is what burned in 2008, and you've learned to plan for the best while expecting the worst.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your independence is both your superpower and your liability. You figured things out on your own because you had to—empty house after school, no parents around, make yourself a snack and do your homework. That self-reliance got you through. But it also means you don't ask for help when you should. You suffer unnecessarily. You assume everyone can figure it out alone, because you did. They can't always. Neither could you, really.

The ironic detachment that served you well at twenty becomes a prison at fifty. You learned not to care too visibly because caring made you vulnerable. But perpetual irony is exhausting. The knowing smirk, the air quotes, the reflexive 'whatever'—at some point, you have to actually commit to something. Caring is risky. It's also the only thing that matters.

You dismiss younger generations too quickly. Yes, Millennials complain about avocado toast. Yes, Gen Z communicates in ways that mystify you. But they're facing problems you didn't: student debt in the six figures, housing costs that doubled and tripled, a job market that treats them as infinitely replaceable. Your 'I figured it out, so can they' ignores that the game changed after you learned the rules. The bootstraps cost more than the boots now.

Your skepticism can curdle into cynicism. Not everything is corrupt. Not everyone in power is lying. Sometimes systems work, sometimes people mean well, sometimes optimism is warranted. Assuming the worst protects you from disappointment, but it also prevents you from pushing for things to improve. Cynicism is safe. It's also passive. It's also, at this point, a little boring.

You underestimate how much technology has changed things. You adapted to smartphones and social media, but you don't feel their effects the way people who grew up immersed feel them. The loneliness epidemic, the mental health crisis, the way algorithms shape reality—these hit different when you've never known anything else. Your 'just put down the phone' advice isn't wrong. It's also insufficient.

And maybe the deepest blind spot: you got lucky on timing and you don't fully acknowledge it. You bought houses before prices tripled. You started careers when entry-level jobs paid living wages. You accumulated assets when accumulation was possible. Not everyone can bootstrap their way to stability when the ladder's been pulled up. Acknowledging luck isn't diminishing your hard work. It's understanding why hard work doesn't work the same way anymore.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1995-2005): You graduated into a decent economy—maybe the last decent economy, in retrospect. Jobs existed. The dot-com boom was heating up. If you had any computer skills, companies threw money at you. Stock options! Foosball! The word 'disruptive' wasn't ironic yet. You moved to cities, dated people, figured out what you wanted from life. Some of you got rich during the boom. Most of you didn't, but the possibility felt real. Then 2000 hit and the bubble burst, teaching you that paper wealth can become paper losses overnight. You recovered. You adapted. That's what you do.

Your 30s (2005-2015): You probably settled down, or decided not to. Marriage, kids, mortgage—the traditional markers happened for some of you. Others chose different paths. By your mid-thirties, you'd built something: career stability, savings, maybe a house. Then 2008 hit when you were thirty-three. The financial crisis didn't just damage your 401(k); it damaged your faith that planning could protect you. You watched friends lose houses. You watched banks get bailed out. You rebuilt anyway, because that's the only option.

Your 40s (2015-2025): The recovery decade. You rebuilt what 2008 damaged—retirement accounts, confidence, the tentative belief that the ground might stay solid. Your kids, if you had them, were growing up. Your parents were aging. You became the responsible adult in the room, whether you wanted that job or not. Career-wise, you either made it to management or realized you didn't want to—the corporate ladder looked different from halfway up. COVID hit when you were forty-five, sending everyone home and reshuffling everything again. Another crisis. Another adaptation.

Your 50s (2025-2035): You're here now, or approaching it. Peak earning years. Peak responsibility. Your kids are launching into a world harder than the one you entered—housing costs double what you paid, job markets that treat workers as disposable. Your parents need more help, and help is expensive. You're thinking about retirement, not sure you can afford it, not sure what you'd do with yourself. You've lived through enough disruption to know more is coming. The question isn't whether the next crisis happens, but what form it takes.

Your 60s and beyond (2035+): Retirement, maybe. Or semi-retirement—working less, choosing projects, staying engaged because idleness was never your style. Social Security will probably exist; whether it's enough is another question. Your health matters more now than it did. The friends who matter have been around for decades. You've earned the right to not care what people think, to say no to things that don't serve you, to spend your time on what actually matters. You survived recessions, pandemics, wars, technological revolutions. Whatever comes next, you'll probably survive that too. You always have.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US the same year as you. Generation X as a whole numbers about 65 million Americans—the smallest generation wedged between two behemoths. 76 million Boomers had the numbers to shape policy. 72 million Millennials had the numbers to shape culture. You had... the ability to be overlooked, which is fine by you. Attention was never the point.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): They got affordable college—you got student loans. They got pensions—you got 401(k)s and 'personal responsibility.' They bought houses for two years' salary—you watched prices triple. They had Woodstock—you had Lollapalooza, which was self-consciously trying to be Woodstock. They believed they could change the world. You believed you could survive it. Both of you were half right.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): You're the older sibling they resent. You bought houses before prices went insane. You started careers when entry-level jobs still paid living wages. They graduated into the 2008 crater; you hit it mid-career. The difference isn't character—it's timing. They expect institutions to work; you expect them to fail. Both positions have evidence on their side.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): You're analogs in a digital world. They've never known life without the internet; you remember rotary phones. They grew up with social media shaping their identity from childhood; you formed your identity first, then got Facebook in your thirties. They're anxious in ways that mystify you. You're dismissive in ways that frustrate them. Neither of you is entirely wrong about the other.

Your life expectancy is around 76-78 years, though 'deaths of despair'—suicide, overdose, alcoholism—have hit Gen X harder than previous generations. The ironic detachment has a cost. Independence can become isolation. Skepticism can curdle into nihilism. Your greatest strength is also your vulnerability: you're so good at not needing anyone that you forget you actually do.

You didn't complain about it—you just did the work. That's your legacy: competence without fanfare. But you've also built lives with less institutional support than any generation before you. No pensions, no job security, no guarantee that the rules would stay stable. You adapted without complaint, raised kids while working, cared for aging parents while saving for uncertain retirements. You can still entertain yourself without a screen. That's a superpower now.

year_events: Vietnam War ended with the fall of Saigon
Microsoft was founded by Bill Gates and Paul Allen
Saturday Night Live premiered on NBC
Jaws became the first summer blockbuster
One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest won Best Picture
